Country_with_Annotation.Papua New Guinea: Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica was the most intense tropical cyclone, in terms of maximum sustained winds, on record to impact Australia. The 17th and final storm of the 2005–06 Australian region cyclone season, Monica originated from an area of low pressure off the coast of Papua New Guinea on 16 April 2006.
Country_with_Annotation.Australia: Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica was the most intense tropical cyclone, in terms of maximum sustained winds, on record to impact Australia. The storm quickly developed into a Category 1 cyclone the next day, at which time it was given the name Monica. Travelling towards the west, the storm intensified into a severe tropical cyclone before making landfall in Far North Queensland, near Lockhart River, on 19 April 2006.

Country_with_Annotation.United States: The Electra Fire was a wildfire that burned northeast of Mokelumne Hill in Amador and Calaveras Counties, California that started on July 4, 2022.

Country_with_Annotation.Australia: The 2008 Queensland storms were a series of three thunderstorms that struck South East Queensland, Australia. The first storm hit on 16 November 2008 and was followed by two further storms on 19 and 20 November. The storms resulted in 2 fatalities.

Country_with_Annotation.Philippines: More than 43 deaths were directly blamed on Sepat; 3 out of the 43 were from the Philippines due to drowning brought on by heavy rains from the southwest monsoon enhanced by Sepat.
Country_with_Annotation.Taiwan: It made landfall in eastern Taiwan between Taitung and Hualien on the morning of August 18 local time at around 5 a.m. (2100 UTC August 17) and weakened to a minimal typhoon.
Country_with_Annotation.China: It made a second landfall, in China, about 24 hours after landfall on Taiwan and was downgraded to a tropical storm the next morning.

Country_with_Annotation.United States: The heat wave affected Northern California, Idaho, Western Nevada, Oregon, and Washington in the United States, as well as British Columbia, and in its latter phase, Alberta, Manitoba, the Northwest Territories, Saskatchewan, and Yukon, all in Canada.
Country_with_Annotation.Canada: The heat wave affected Northern California, Idaho, Western Nevada, Oregon, and Washington in the United States, as well as British Columbia, and in its latter phase, Alberta, Manitoba, the Northwest Territories, Saskatchewan, and Yukon, all in Canada.

Country_with_Annotation.Bahamas: An area of low pressure consolidated near the Bahamas and was classified as Tropical Depression Sixteen on September 6. Stuck in a region of meager steering currents, largely dominated by a lull between two ridges to the north and east, this system moved along a looping course with a general northward trajectory.
Country_with_Annotation.United States: Hurricane Ophelia was a long-lived tropical cyclone in September 2005 that moved along an erratic path off the East Coast of the United States for much of its existence. The greatest impacts were felt in North Carolina, where more than 240,000 people lost power and more than 1,500 homes were damaged.
Country_with_Annotation.Canada: Becoming embedded within the westerlies, Ophelia transitioned into an extratropical cyclone the next day. Remaining on a steady east-northeast to northeast path for the next week, Ophelia traversed Atlantic Canada and the northern Atlantic Ocean before dissipating on September 23 over the Norwegian Sea.

Country_with_Annotation.India: Following heavy rain in July and August 2017, the Indian state of West Bengal was affected by severe flooding. The floods were reported to have caused 50 deaths since 1 August and 8 deaths in the neighbouring state of Jharkhand.

Country_with_Annotation.Andorra: On 15 June, Andorra's weather agency, the National Meteorological Service of Andorra, issued a 'significant danger weather warning' due to heat.
Country_with_Annotation.Austria: On 30 June, a temperature of 36.7Â°C (98.1Â°F) was recorded in Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, this was also Austria's heat record for June.
Country_with_Annotation.Belgium: On 19 July, the temperature reached 38.1Â°C (100.6Â°F) in Uccle, with the highest temperature that day being 40.0Â°C (104.0Â°F) in Kapelle-op-den-Bos.
Country_with_Annotation.Croatia: The heat dome which caused extreme temperatures in north-west Europe was expected to affect Croatia from 21 to 24 July.
Country_with_Annotation.Denmark: On 20 July, it reached 35.9Â°C (96.6Â°F) in Abed, Stokkemarke Parish, Lolland Municipality, breaking the all-time temperature record for that month.
Country_with_Annotation.Finland: Finland was hit by the heatwaves in late June and early July. The highest temperature of 32.5Â°C (90.5Â°F) was measured on 29 June in Utsjoki.
Country_with_Annotation.France: On 16 June, Météo-France activated its red alert in 12 departments and its orange alert in another 25 because of the heatwave.
Country_with_Annotation.Germany: From 14 to 20 June, Germany saw 1,636 probable heat-related deaths attributed to temperatures reaching 39.2Â°C (102.6Â°F).
Country_with_Annotation.Greece: From mid–June to mid–August, Greece experienced one of its biggest heatwaves.
Country_with_Annotation.Hungary: On 22 July, a temperature of 38.5Â°C (101.3Â°F) was reported at Újpest in Budapest, which broke the maximum temperature record for that day in the city.
Country_with_Annotation.Iceland: On 15 August 2022 the temperature reached 30.1Â°C (86.2Â°F) in Neskaupstadur. It was Iceland's warmest day since 22 June 1939.
Country_with_Annotation.Ireland: Met Éireann issued a high-temperature advisory on 13 July, with temperatures forecast to reach the high 20s and possibly exceeding 30Â°C (86Â°F) from 17 to 19 July.
Country_with_Annotation.Italy: In Italy, the number of wildfires was three times the historical average by the end of June.
Country_with_Annotation.Luxembourg: On 18 June, the temperature reached 33.8Â°C (92.8Â°F) in Luxembourg City.
Country_with_Annotation.Malta: June was record warm for Malta, and the temperature reached a record high for June with 39.0Â°C (102.2Â°F) on 28 June.
Country_with_Annotation.Netherlands: On 18 July, the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute issued a code orange heat warning for the central and southern provinces.
Country_with_Annotation.Norway: In July, the Norwegian Meteorological Institute reported that several areas may reach temperatures higher than 30Â°C (86Â°F).
Country_with_Annotation.Poland: On 19 June, temperatures in western Poland exceeded 36Â°C (97Â°F). In Słubice, the highest temperature was 38.3Â°C (100.9Â°F).
Country_with_Annotation.Portugal: According to Instituto Português do Mar e da Atmosfera (IPMA), the heatwave was the longest and had the greatest area extension of any July heatwave in Portugal since 1941.
Country_with_Annotation.San Marino: In late July, San Marino experienced a heatwave. On 24 July the temperature reached 39.6Â°C (103.3Â°F) in Dogana.
Country_with_Annotation.Serbia: On 23 July the temperature reached 40.0Â°C (104.0Â°F) in Niš, only 4.9Â°C under the record from 2007.
Country_with_Annotation.Slovakia: The first tropical day (Slovak: tropický deň), a day with a temperature of over 30Â°C (86Â°F) as defined by the Slovak Hydrometeorological Institute, was recorded in Dolné Plachtince on 22 June.
Country_with_Annotation.Slovenia: On 28 June, the Slovenian Environment Agency (ARSO) recorded a temperature of 38.0Â°C (100.4Â°F) in Podnanos.
Country_with_Annotation.Spain: A special heat warning was activated by the AEMET on 10 June, but only for 12 provinces and with yellow alerts in Aragon, Castilla-La Mancha, Catalonia, Extremadura and Madrid.
Country_with_Annotation.Switzerland: On 15 June, a heat-wave alert was activated in the canton of Ticino.
Country_with_Annotation.United Kingdom: On 14 June, in view of the Met Office's forecast of high temperatures, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) issued level 2 'alert and readiness' alerts in several regions.
Country_with_Annotation.Vatican: The Vatican was also affected by the heatwave like surrounding Italy. On 28 June 2022, the Vatican measured its highest temperature ever recorded when the temperature reached 40.8Â°C (105.4Â°F).

Country_with_Annotation.Mexico: Though it moved slowly across the Yucatán Peninsula, the damage Agnes caused in Mexico is unknown.

Country_with_Annotation.Cuba: Although the storm bypassed the tip of Cuba, heavy rainfall occurred, killing seven people.

Country_with_Annotation.United States: In the United States, Agnes affected 15 states and the capital area of Washington D.C. Almost 110,000 houses were ruined by Agnes, 3,351 of which were destroyed.

Country_with_Annotation.Canada: In Canada, a mobile home was toppled, killing two people.

Country_with_Annotation.Iceland: A stronger system moving in from the west finally absorbed Agnes on July 6, while located to the southeast of Iceland.

Country_with_Annotation.British Isles: The system turned northeast, strengthening one more time while accelerating across the Hebrides on July 4 through 5.
